DataElement.preferredName: Human Papillomavirus DNA Polymerase Chain Reaction Performed Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The text response that indicates whether or not Human Papillomavirus DNA status was assessed by polymerase chain reaction.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Human Papillomavirus DNA Polymerase Chain Reaction Performed
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The viral DNA that originates from a human papillomavirus._A method for amplifying a DNA base sequence using multiple rounds of heat denaturation of the DNA and annealing of oligonucleotide primers complementary to flanking regions in the presence of a heat-stable polymerase.  This results in duplication of the targeted DNA region. Newly synthesized DNA strands can subsequently serve as additional templates for the same primer sequences, so that successive rounds of primer annealing, strand elongation, and dissociation produce rapid and highly specific amplification of the desired sequence. PCR also can be used to detect the existence of the defined sequence in a DNA sample._Executed and carried through to completion.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The viral DNA that originates from a human papillomavirus.

Concepts.definition: The viral DNA that originates from a human papillomavirus.

Property.preferredDefinition: A method for amplifying a DNA base sequence using multiple rounds of heat denaturation of the DNA and annealing of oligonucleotide primers complementary to flanking regions in the presence of a heat-stable polymerase.  This results in duplication of the targeted DNA region. Newly synthesized DNA strands can subsequently serve as additional templates for the same primer sequences, so that successive rounds of primer annealing, strand elongation, and dissociation produce rapid and highly specific amplification of the desired sequence. PCR also can be used to detect the existence of the defined sequence in a DNA sample.:Executed and carried through to completion.

Concepts.definition: A method for amplifying a DNA base sequence using multiple rounds of heat denaturation of the DNA and annealing of oligonucleotide primers complementary to flanking regions in the presence of a heat-stable polymerase.  This results in duplication of the targeted DNA region. Newly synthesized DNA strands can subsequently serve as additional templates for the same primer sequences, so that successive rounds of primer annealing, strand elongation, and dissociation produce rapid and highly specific amplification of the desired sequence. PCR also can be used to detect the existence of the defined sequence in a DNA sample.
Executed and carried through to completion.
